Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Does genetic load drive mating system evolution? Tests in an explicit historical context
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will quantify the interplay between historical events and current natural selection in shaping plant mating system. Evolution is an ongoing process but depends strongly on the past. While nearly everyone acknowledges this fact, it has been difficult to quantify the relative importance of historical and current selection pressures as explanations of patterns in nature. This research will look at the factors that have determined the amount of self-pollination versus outcrossing in the American bellflower (Campanulastrum americanum). The project will immerse undergraduate and graduate students in the collection of next-generation DNA sequence data to reconstruct historical events and studies of current selective environment in the study species. Analyses of data from these disparate sources into a single, unified framework will provide a clearer understanding of the processes shaping complex patterns in nature, and yields a predictive framework that can be applied in any biological system. Broad dissemination of this predictive approach is valuable because it will help predict the response of species to increasingly altered environments in the modern age.

Plant mating systems are evolutionarily labile, ranging from highly outcrossing to highly inbreeding. This wide variation provides an excellent system for understanding the ultimate drivers of evolutionary change. Variable mating system strategies across levels of the biological hierarchy are commonly explained as adaptations to the current selective environment. A significant fraction of this variation, however, may reflect historical evolution in response to colonization during range expansion. This idea will be tested using Campanulastrum americanum, a North American herb in which preliminary data indicate reduced inbreeding depression and greater autogamy in sites where phylogeographic data suggest recent colonization. Using populations a range of distances from glacial refugia, the researchers will gather data with coalescent analysis of RAD-seq polymorphism, greenhouse studies of fixed and segregating genetic load, field studies of pollen limitation and reproductive assurance, and population-genetic inferences of selfing rates. Analyses of these data will determine whether initially non-adaptive processes associated with range expansion provided a permissive environment for later evolution of the mating system. The research framework therefore provides a mechanism for discerning the ultimate drivers of organismal change across past and present time scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

A major goal of evolutionary science is to explain patterns in the world's biodiversity. One of the most labile traits in plants and invertebrates is the degree to which organisms mate with themselves (i.e. self-fertilize). Self-fertility evolves frequently in nature and often limits the viability and duration of lineages through time, so understanding why selfing traits evolve may reveal potential threats to biodiversity. In this project, we studied a strong geographic cline in the ability of plants to mate with themselves (i.e. self-fertilize) in the polyploid American bellflower (Campanula americana).  Using compelling natural variation observed in 24 populations across the species range, we asked the following questions:

#1): Is the ability of plants to self-fertilize (i.e. auto-fertility) explained by limits on pollinators or mates within natural populations?

#2): Does the degree of outcrossing among populations reflect the availability of outcross pollen, genetic differentiation in the ability to self-fertilize, or both?

#3): Is there evidence that the ability to self-fertilize is enriched in populations with a history of colonizing new environments?

#4) In polyploids, does the expression of harmful mutations decline during the colonization of new environments, as is expected in diploids?

We found that the geography of auto-fertility was poorly explained by contemporary pollination environments (#1). This trait is not elevated in populations that are small, have fewer pollinators, or those with pollen limitation. The auto-fertility of populations also does not have a simple influence on outcrossing. Auto-fertility interacts with pollen limitation -- only populations with high auto-fertility self-fertilize more when pollen limitation was pronounced (#2). The geography of auto-fertility is therefore poorly explained by studying contemporary environments. Plants that encounter pollen-limited environments produce more selfed offspring, but this is true only for populations that have evolved traits enhancing auto-fertility.  

In addition, we challenged the hypothesis that historical biogeography has shaped the evolution of traits. Specifically, we tested the idea that the colonization of new environments has selected for high levels of auto-fertility in some natural populations. This would be expected if the species range recently expanded from a glacial refugium sometime during the Pleistocene. We found compelling support for this hypothesis, since auto-fertility and mutation load are strongly associated with distance from a glacial refugium inferred from footprints of genetic drift on genome-wide variation (#3). To complement our empirical work, we also modeled how colonization events (i.e. population bottlenecks) influence the expression of harmful mutations in polyploids. Under reasonable assumptions, this important factor does not always decline during colonization (#4). 

In sum, this work shows that auto-fertility evolves during the colonization of new environments and best reflects biogeographic history. We further demonstrate that this important trait may often be poorly explained by the environmental conditions experienced by organisms in recent time. 

Broader Impacts

Beyond addressing the questions above in published papers, the research directly supported the training of a diverse team of students (two postdocs, three PhD students, one MS student, and five undergraduates), the majority of which were female. Our group gave thirteen presentations and five posters at professional meetings and five invited talks at universities. Six peer-reviewed papers have been generated thus far, with an additional three to be submitted in 2020. Students were trained to generate and interpret next-generation sequencing data, which is an essential skill for careers in science and/or agricultural contexts. Finally, analyses of population genomic data have been incorporated into "R workshops" in the PI's graduate course in Population Genetics. This course draws students from many disciplines at a land grant institution to tackle pressing societal problems with genetic data.
